entry.title: Color of Tandoori Chicken
entry.content:
Tandoori chicken is a favorite dish that is served as a stand alone dish or along with Briyani. It goes well with Mutton Briyani or Kushkaa. If you find that meat in your briyani is sparse, you may buy a tandoori along with it.

The good thing about Tandoori is unlike Chicken 65 that is fried in oil, this one uses very less oil. First chicken cut in right places and is marinated in certain type of masalas for hours, this makes sure the meat become tender, juicy and absorbs the flavoring. Next the chicken is lowered in coal fired oven.

Coal fire is important as coal has and adds an unique flavor to the dish. Coal on burning emits no water vapor. Tandoori is formed when water evaporates from the chicken and is replaced by oils in the chicken. Occasionally the chef might take the chicken out and brush oil on top of it.

Here in this blog we are talking about the color of the tandoori. Is it reddish like the image above or is it brownish as shown below

If you say its like the first image you must watch out. To say the truth, food coloring is no way associated with taste of the food. Its just to make the food attractive to look. Next there is issue of health, its gossiped that coloring is not good for health. So who knows?

What we advise people is to goto restaurants that serve tandoori in which natural color, i.e kinda brown comes out and not the fake red. Possibly long term ingestion of food coloring might prove bad for your health.

Do you know a restaurant that serves Tandoori with natural colors? Then do let people know by commenting.

References

  • Are You or Your Family Eating Toxic Food Dyes?

entry.title: Brinjal Gothsu
entry.content:
Ingredients

  • Small purple brinjal chopped - 10 numbers
  • Onion small chopped - 1 number
  • Tomato small chopped - 1 number
  • Green chilly slit - 2 numbers
  • Garlic cloves sliced - 4 numbers
  • Tamarind - Gooseberry size
  • Red chilly powder - 1 tsp
  • Turmeric powder - 1/4 tsp
  • Salt to taste
  • Curry leaves - few
  • Mustard seeds - 1 tsp
  • Urad dal - 1 tsp
  • Asafoetida - 1/4 tsp
  • Oil - 2 tsp
  • Water - 1 cup + 1/4 cup

Method

  1. Soak gooseberry size tamarind in 1/4 cup water for 10 mins. Extract tamarind pulp, filter and discard residue.
  2. In a vessel add chopped brinjal, chopped onion, chopped tomato, sliced garlic, slit green chilli, tamarind pulp, turmeric powder, red chilli powder, required salt and 1 cup water. Mix well and place vessel inside pressure cooker and pressure cook for 3 whistles or 10 mins.
  3. Heat oil in a pan when hot add mustard seeds, urad dal, curry leaves and asafoetida. When the mustard splutters add to the cooked brinjal gravy and stir well.
  4. Bring Brinjal Gothsu to boil and remove from heat. Serve with Venpongal, Idli or Dosa.

entry.title: Salem R.R Briyani in Medavakkam
entry.content:
This is a review of Salem R.R restaurant at Medavkkam. As far as our experience goes, Salem R.R was first visited when it was in Chitlapakkam near Tambaram East. People say it was first a parotta shop when there was huge lorry traffic in Velacherry Tambaram road. We have tasted it parotta and in Chitlapakkam it was excellent.

Then this shop became a Briyani shop too. Though its Briyani is not really good one, it became famous with low price paying masses because it offered good quantity of rice compared to other shops. This shop also has prepackaged briyani. Just walk into the shop pay your bill, walk to briyani counter and you have briyani to take away in a minute. Definitely the management knows to streamline process.

We recently visited this hotel in Medavakkam, and to say the truth, this restaurant is okay. Its clean enough has no fancy paintaings and all those things to make it feel its posh, but a half chicken briyani now costs Rs 150/-. But it has good quantity of rice in it.

Some time prior the rice quantity was reduced, possibly it was comparable to A.R. Rahmans quantity, but Salem R.R’s tastes like glorified pulisaadham with masala and meat added to it, so possibly seeing sales drop they have increased the rice quantity once again.

What ever might be the reason, if you are going for briyani taste, then this restaurant is something that may be avoided, but if you are really hungry and don’t bother much about the quality then this restaurant can be visited.

The quantity of chicken in briyani too is very less. Not enough meat to go with every bite, but now possibly seeing Salem R.R and possibly to increase profit, A.R Rahman too has reduced meat quantity.

entry.title: Dumpuhkt Chicken
entry.content:
Dumpukht means slow oven in Persian. It has become one of the most refined forms of cooking in India and Pakistan, even though the technique is no more than 200 years old. Slow oven means cooking on very low flame, mostly in sealed containers, allowing the meats to cook, as much as possible, in their own juices. Here we have a modified version of Dumpukht for your conviniance.

Preparation time: Overnight + 40 minutes

Cooking time: 1 Hour

Serves: 3 - 4 people

Ingredients

  • Chicken 1 whole
  • Boiled rice 1 cup
  • Crushed Black pepper 1 tbsp
  • Turmeric ½ tsp
  • Red chili powder 1 tsp
  • Salt 1 tsp
  • Black pepper ½ tsp (whole)
  • Lemon Juice 4 table sp
  • Ginger/Garlic paste 1 tbsp
  • Almonds 10
  • Raisins 1 tbsp
  • Honey 1 tbsp
  • Butter 2 tbsp
  • Oil 2 tbsp

Procedure

Clean chicken, marinate it with salt, lemon juice and refrigerate it for one whole night.

Make a paste with mixing oil, ginger/garlic paste, crushed black pepper, turmeric and red chili powder.

Also marinate the chicken in and out with the mixture and leave for half an hour.

Fry the dry fruits in butter and add boiled rice,mix well.

Now, add honey and black pepper whole and fill chicken with the rice.

Preheat oven 200 degree and bake chicken for 40 minutes.

entry.title: A.R.Rahman Briyani is not as good as before

link.title: A.R.Rahman Briyani is not as good as before

entry.content:
This is Namma Samayal’s experience with A.R.Rahman briyani. We were dining in Medavakkam restaurant for a long time, the quality used to be near perfect, but now it has dropped significantly. Notably the amount of meat in chicken briyani has dropped significantly.

Before a chicken briyani used to have nice two huge pieces of meat that was copious. When we ate we used to have meat in almost every bite, now the meat has dropped just to one piece and mostly its the leg piece with little meat attached to it.

When A.R Rahman opened in Medavakkam, it was the place to go, but now it has become just another restaurant which serves just another medium quality briyani with very less meat.

Its quiet sad that restaurant we cherished for briyani has become like this.
